section.title: Troubleshooting your Barbican Setup
section.para: If you cannot find the answers you’re looking for within this document, you can ask questions on the Freenode IRC channel #openstack-barbican

section.title: Getting a Barbican HTTP 401 error after a successful authentication to Keystone
What you might see
section.para: You get a HTTP 401 Unauthorized response even with a valid token

section.title: Caused by
section.para: Expired signing cert on the Barbican server.

section.title: How to avoid
section.para: Check for an expired Keystone signing certificate on your Barbican server. Look at the expiration date in /tmp/barbican/cache/signing_cert.pem. If it is expired then follow these steps.

step.para: On your Keystone server, verify that signing_cert.pem has the same expiration date as the one on your Barbican machine. You can normally find signing_cert.pem on your Keystone server in /etc/keystone/ssl/certs.
If the cert matches then follow these steps to create a new one
Delete it from both your Barbican and Keystone servers.
Edit /etc/keystone/ssl/certs/index.txt.attr and set unique_subject to no.
Run keystone-manage pki_setup to create a new signing_cert.pem
The updated cert will be downloaded to your Barbican server the next time you hit the Barbican API.

If the cert doesn’t match then delete the signing_cert.pem from your Barbican server. Do not delete from Keystone. The cert from Keystone will be downloaded to your machine the next time you hit the Barbican API.

section.title: Returned refs use localhost instead of the correct hostname
Caused by
section.para: The default configuration on the response host name is not modified to the endpoint’s host name (typically the load balancer’s DNS name and port).

section.title: How to avoid
section.para: Change your barbican.conf file’s host_href setting from localhost:9311 to the correct host name (myhostname.com in the example above).

section.title: Barbican’s tox tests fail to run on my Mac
How to avoid
section.para: There is a great blog article that provides more details on the error and how to work around it. This link provides more details on the error and how to work around it.

section.title: Barbican’s tox tests fail to find ffi.h on my Mac
What you might see
section.screen: c/_cffi_backend.c:13:10: fatal error: 'ffi.h' file not found ... ERROR: could not install deps [...]; v = InvocationError('...', 1)

section.title: How to avoid
section.para: Be sure that xcode and cmd line tools are up to date. Easiest way is to run xcode-select --install from an OS X command line. Be sure to say yes when asked if you want to install the command line tools. Now ls /usr/include/ffi/ffi.h should show that missing file exists, and the tox tests should run.

section.title: Barbican’s tox tests fail with “ImportError: No module named _bsddb”
How to avoid
section.para: Running tests via tox (which uses testr) will create a .testrepository directory containing, among other things, data files. Those datafiles may be created with bsddb, if it is available in the environment. This can cause problems if you run in an environment that does not have bsddb. To resolve this, delete your .testrepository directory and run tox again.

section.title: Caused by
section.para: The vassal (worker) processes are not able to access the datastore.

section.title: How to avoid
section.para: Check the sql_connection in your barbican.conf file, to make sure that it references a valid reachable database.

section.title: “Cannot register CLI option” error when importing logging
What you might see
section.screen: ... File ".../oslo_config/cfg.py", line 1275, in register_cli_opt raise ArgsAlreadyParsedError("cannot register CLI option") ArgsAlreadyParsedError: arguments already parsed: cannot register CLI option

section.title: Caused by
section.para: An attempt to call the olso.config’s register_cli_opt() function after the configuration arguments were ‘parsed’ (see the comments and method in the oslo.config project’s cfg.py file for details.

section.title: How to avoid
section.para: Instead of calling import barbican.openstack.common.log as logging to get a logger, call from barbican.common import config with this to get a logger to use in your source file: LOG = config.getLogger(__name__).

section.title: Responder raised TypeError: ‘NoneType’ object has no attribute ‘__getitem__’
What you might see
section.screen: ... 2013-04-14 14:17:56 [FALCON] [ERROR] POST \ /da71dfbc-a959-4ad3-bdab-5ee190ce7515/csrs? => Responder raised \ TypeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute '__getitem__'

section.title: Caused by
section.para: Forgetting to set your non-nullable FKs in entities you create via XxxxResource classes.

section.title: How to avoid
section.para: Don’t forget to set any FKs defined on an entity prior to using the repository to create it.

section.title: uWSGI config issue: ImportError: No module named site
What you might see
section.screen: ... uwsgi socket 0 bound to TCP address :9311 fd 3 Python version: 2.7.3 (...) [...] Set PythonHome to ./.venv ImportError: No module named site

listitem.para: Can’t locate the Python virtualenv for the Barbican project.
Either the ‘broker’ setting above is incorrect, or else you haven’t started a queue process yet (such as RabbitMQ)

section.title: How to avoid
section.para: Make sure the uWSGI config file at etc/barbican/barbican-api-paste.ini is configured correctly (see installation steps above), esp. if the virtualenv folder is named differently than the .ini file has.

section.title: REST Request Fails with JSON error
Caused by
section.para: Barbican REST server cannot parse the incoming JSON message from your REST client.

section.title: How to avoid
section.para: Make sure you are submitting properly formed JSON. For example, are there commas after all but the last name/value pair in a list? Are there quotes around all name/values that are text-based? Are the types of values matching what is expected (i.e. integer and boolean types instead of quoted text)?

If you are using the Advanced REST Client with Chrome, and you tried to upload a file to the secrets PUT call, not only will this fail due to the multi-part format it uses, but it will also try to submit this file for every REST request you make thereafter, causing this error. Close the tab/window with the client, and restart it again.

section.title: Crypto Mime Type Not Supported when I try to run tests or hit the API
What you might see
section.para: A stack trace that has this in it (for example):
section.screen: CryptoMimeTypeNotSupportedException: Crypto Mime Type of 'text/plain' not \ supported

section.title: Caused by
section.para: The Barbican plugins are not installed into a place where the Python plugin manager can find them.

section.title: How to avoid
section.para: Make sure you run the pip install -e ..

section.title: Caused by
section.para: The Barbican source modules are not found in the Python path of applications such as uwsgi.

section.title: How to avoid
section.para: Make sure you are running from your virtual env, and that pip was executed after you activated your virtual environment. This especially includes the pip install -e command. Also, it is possible that your virtual env gets corrupted, so you might need to rebuild it.

section.title: ‘unable to open database file None None’ errors running scripts
What you might see
section.screen: ... File "./site-packages/sqlalchemy/engine/strategies.py", line 80, in connect return dialect.connect(*cargs, **cparams) File "./site-packages/sqlalchemy/engine/default.py", line 283, in connect return self.dbapi.connect(*cargs, **cparams) OperationalError: (OperationalError) unable to open database file None None [emperor] removed uwsgi instance barbican-api.ini ...

section.title: Caused by
section.para: Destination folder for the sqlite database is not found, or is not writable.

section.title: How to avoid
section.para: Make sure the /var/lib/barbican/ folder exists and is writable by the user that is running the Barbican API process.

What you might see
section.screen: ... 2013-08-15 16:55:15.759 2445 DEBUG keystoneclient.middleware.auth_token \ [-] Token validation failure. _validate_user_token \ ./site-packages/keystoneclient/middleware/auth_token.py:711 ... 2013-08-15 16:55:15.759 2445 TRACE keystoneclient.middleware.auth_token \ raise ValueError("No JSON object could be decoded") 2013-08-15 16:55:15.759 24458 TRACE keystoneclient.middleware.auth_token \ ValueError: No JSON object could be decoded ... 2013-08-15 16:55:15.766 2445 WARNING keystoneclient.middleware.auth_token \ [-] Authorization failed for token ... 2013-08-15 16:55:15.766 2445 INFO keystoneclient.middleware.auth_token \ [-] Invalid user token - rejecting request...

section.title: Caused by
section.para: The keystoneclient middleware component is looking for a cms command in openssl that wasn’t available before version 1.0.1.

section.title: How to avoid
section.para: Update openssl.

section.title: What you might see
section.screen: Secret retrieval issue seen - accept-encoding of 'gzip,deflate,sdch' not \ supported

section.title: Caused by
section.para: This might be an issue with the browser you are using, as performing the request via curl doesn’t seem to be affected.

section.title: How to avoid
section.para: Other than using an command such as curl to make the REST request you may not have many other options.
